keyTakeAways: A steel cable in the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed and snapped during operation, causing a deadly crash that killed at least 16 people and injured others.
The cable did not meet the specifications set by CARRIS, the funicular’s operator, and failed to pass certification standards.
The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in cable integrity, maintenance practices, and brake systems.
Maintenance tasks were falsely marked as completed, even though they were not properly performed, and the maintenance plan was recorded as compliant despite deficiencies.
Eyewitnesses described the crash as chaotic, with one man named Bruno recalling the car derailing and producing a loud bang and brown smoke.
The preliminary report is not conclusive, and a final report is expected to be released next year.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fatal cable failure on the Glória funicular in Lisbon, Portugal, killed at least 16 people and injured several others when a steel cable snapped during operation on Calçada da Glória. A preliminary investigation by the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) found that the cable failed to meet CARRIS’s operational specifications, maintenance tasks were incorrectly marked as completed, and the maintenance plan was falsely declared compliant. Eyewitnesses, including a man named Bruno, described the crash as chaotic and violent. The interim findings are not conclusive, and a final report is expected next year, underscoring ongoing concerns about safety protocols in public transportation systems.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
